reviewText: but too many vocals are weak. There are two older ladies who sing well enough but the two younger ladies have no apparent talent whatsoever. The other major problem is that even though John Mclaughlin is on stage for most of the show, you rarely hear him. Instead we hear numerous saxophone solos played by reputable musicians who seem to be having a seriously off night. Still, if you can get past the frequently bad vocals and solos its still a decent show.
summary: Good idea and nice change for Santana
Title: N/A

reviewText: I enjoyed this performance in some respects, but was disappointed in others.The show feels like it was put together haphazardly. They did not have enough cameras on stage to properly cover the musicians when they played. Or, the director was incompetent, take your pick. There are several musicians, e.g. Chick Corea and Stevie Winwood, that you NEVER get to see their hands when they're playing. WTF! There are no musician credits on the blu-ray. WTF! And the audio mix is poor. Soloists, esp. sax players, are left way too deep in the mix.Video is ok esp.considering the excess fx smoke.The band takes 3-4 songs to really get cooking. This show is more like a jam session with Santana obviously directing when artists solo. It doesn't have the polish of the Return to Forever blu-ray, a state-of-the-art blu-ray for sound, video quality. performance and directing. Most of the artists deliver, although McLaughlin seemed out of his element at times. A typical McLaughlin solo just didn't play well for me during a boogie tune.Corea & Hancock look like they just awoke from a dream and found themselves on stage. The percussion is great - 2-3  drummers + congas.This disk gets 3.5 stars for the musicians' performances, 2 for the production. This could be remixed to sound much better.
Title: N/A

Title: N/A

reviewText: 1st - Santana is one of the best groups ever. I go back to the Woodstock days with them.Now - Sacred Fire (1993) is what Santana is all about in my book.So, in order to find material such as Sacred Fire, one must look to the bootleg market. Well, Santana's management has pretty much wiped out any Internet sales of bootlegs.Anyways - YES they still CAN perform as they did in Sacred Fire. BUT, the only resent (filmed) kick-ass performances I know of where done in 2006 in Portugal & Japan. It's a crying shame Carlos doesn't release stuff like these performances.I don't know what he is thinking, but his stuff being released as of lately has left me cold.This DVD would be nice for a tea party or a family get togather. But, to rock out on, forget it.Sorry Carlos - I'm getting your good stuff while I can thru the black market.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Hey, if you're a Santana fan from back in the Woodstock days, and appreciate energetic pop music too, and have a special place in your heart for Jingo and Bob Marley's Exodus, then I cant see how you cant not get high off this DVD and Santana's authentic spiritual vibe.  A true master has assembled a great band for a great evening to be shared with all.  Enjoy. 'Jazz' critics, feh.
summary: Some great stuff here, jazz purists should keep seeking perfection elsewhere
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a pop extravaganza.  The like of which Carlos is only recently known for.  (Remember George Benson?)  The jazz musicians on the title play for very very little time in any kind of jazz/improv format.  The vast majority of the DVD is singers singing non-jazz songs which are backed up by some of the Jazz musicians.  There is one jam towards the beginning where they all get about 8 bars.  Then later John and Carlos play "Enter the house of the lord"  ALL and I said "ALL" of the rest (even jazz titles) are pop type songs. On the other hand if you havn't had enough of "The Banana Boat Song" then this DVD is for you.  As for me.  My money is gone.But do get the Santana and Shorter DVD. That is great. That cooks.a
summary: WARNING !  Jazzer's keep dough in pockets.
